name: Vernal Pool Tadpole Shrimp
overview: Unique compared to other fairy shrimps, they are quite different. They look similar to a tiny horseshoe crab, it has a shield-like carapace with compound eyes. It has 48 swimming appendages and two cercopods with are pincer-like appendages at the end of the tail segment. The distinguishing feature from males and females are the eggs sacs that the females have, and both sexes are about 2.5 inches long.They can be seen in the spring and are endangered.
habitat: They need vernal pool habitats to live, and are found throughout the Central Coast, Sacramento Valley, San Joaquin Valley, and southern Sierra Nevada foothills, but are most common in the Sacramento Valley. When UC Merced was being constructed originally, it was going to built on the vernal pool habitat area, but that plan was changed and now is a valuable habitat for them.
tags: Vernal Pool Tadpole Shrimp Lepidurus packardi Fairy Shrimp Crab animal animals
